questions.question: Which among the following are Skeletal derivatives of 3rd pharyngeal arch? Greater cornu of hyoid Stylohyoid ligament Lesser cornu of hyoid Upper half of body of hyoid Lower half of body of hyoid
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 1 and 5 Explanation: Arch Nerve of arch Artery of arch Skeletal derivatives (Option D) Muscles of arch Third Glossopharyngeal nerve Common carotid artery Internal carotid artery Greater cornu of hyoid Lower half of body of hyoid Stylopharyngeus Reference: Inderbir Singh’s Human Embryology, 11th Edition, Page 129, 130.

questions.question: Arrange the events in the development of the thyroid gland in the correct sequence: Fusion with caudal pharyngeal complex Formation of pharyngeal arches Thyroglossal duct formation Tuberculum impar is formed
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 2,4,3,1 Explanation: Development of thyroid gland:

questions.question: Which of the following statements on double aortic arch is false?

options.D: Right aortic arch passes in front of the trachea and esophagus

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Right aortic arch passes in front of the trachea and esophagus Explanation: In a double aortic arch, the right aortic arch passes behind the trachea and esophagus, not in front of it. Double aortic arch: A developmental anomaly in which a vascular ring surrounds the trachea and esophagus. The dorsal aorta is a midline artery dorsal to the gut In normal development, the right dorsal aorta between the origin of the 7th cervical intersegmental artery and its fusion with the left dorsal aorta disappears. In this case, the right dorsal aorta persisted. The right aortic arch passes behind the trachea and esophagus. (Option D) The left aortic arch passes in front of the trachea and esophagus, forming a vascular ring. The vascular ring compresses the trachea and esophagus, leading to dyspnea and dysphagia Reference: Inderbir Singh’s Human Embryology, 11th Edition, Page 173, 243-246, 262.

questions.question: Which pharyngeal arch primarily contributes to the development of the anterior two-thirds of the tongue?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) First pharyngeal arch Explanation: Development of tongue: Begins around the fourth week of intrauterine life. Anterior 2/3rd of tongue: The development begins with the growth of medial swelling from the first pharyngeal arch known as tuberculum impar. Gradually, two lateral lingual swellings start to grow in the 5th week from the same arch. As the lateral swelling grows in size they eventually merge and overlap tuberculum impar leading to the formation of anterior 2/3rd of tongue. Posterior 1/3rd of tongue: From the mesoderm of the 2nd, 3rd and 4th pharyngeal arches, a median swelling known as hypobranchial eminence begins to develop and forms the posterior 1/3rd of the tongue. Posterior most of tongue: Develops from third median swelling arising from fourth pharyngeal arch. Taste buds development: First sign of taste bud development on lingual epithelium occurs at 8th week of gestation. Between 9-11th week of gestation, many taste bud primordia develop. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK547697/#:~:text=The%20tongue%20begins%20to%20develop, arch,%20known%20as%20tuberculum%20impar.

questions.question: A 4-year-old child presents with recurrent infections and signs of hypocalcemia. Investigation shows low levels of parathyroid hormone. The physician suspects an embryological defect. Which among the following could be a possible reason?

options.A: Defect in the development of 1st pharyngeal pouch
options.B: Defect in the development of 2nd pharyngeal pouch
options.C: Defect in the development of 3rd pharyngeal pouch
options.D: Defect in the development of 5th pharyngeal pouch

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Defect in the development of 3rd pharyngeal pouch Explanation : Here the scenario is suggestive of defect in thymus development (recurrent infections) and defect in development of parathyroid gland ( signs of hypocalcemia and low levels of parathyroid hormone). The 3rd pharyngeal pouch is responsible for the development of thymus and inferior parathyroid gland while the 4th pharyngeal pouch is responsible for the development of superior parathyroid gland. Hence, there could be a defect in only the 3rd pharyngeal pouch or defect could be in both 3rd and 4th pharyngeal pouches. Pharyngeal arches, clefts and pouches Pharyngeal arches Pharyngeal arches are key structures in head and neck development, appearing in the fourth and fifth weeks as mesenchymal tissue bars. They resemble gills but do not function as such in humans. Pharyngeal arches are divided by pharyngeal clefts on the outside and pharyngeal pouches on the inside. Pharyngeal pouches develop as outpocketings from the lateral walls of the pharynx and do not connect to the exterior, playing crucial roles in organ development. Each arch incorporates neural crest cells essential for forming facial skeleton components, while mesoderm differentiates into facial and neck musculature. Each arch has its own cranial nerve and artery. Pharyngeal Pouches Four Pairs (fifth is rudimentary) First Pouch : Forms the middle ear cavity and Eustachian tube, contributes to the tympanic membrane. Second Pouch : Develops into palatine tonsils; remnants persist as the tonsillar fossa. Third Pouch: Dorsal wing becomes the inferior parathyroid gland; ventral wing forms the thymus, migrating to the thorax. Fourth Pouch : Dorsal region forms the superior parathyroid gland; ventral region becomes the ultimobranchial body, integrating into the thyroid. Pharyngeal Clefts Five-week-old Embryo: Four clefts are present. First Cleft: Does not form the external auditory meatus (EAM); instead, the EAM arises from surface ectoderm invagination. It eventually disappears due to overgrowth by the second arch. Second, Third, and Fourth Clefts: Overgrown by the second arch, they lose exterior contact and may temporarily form the cervical sinus, which ultimately disappears.

questions.question: Which of the following muscles of the first pharyngeal arch are migratory? Mylohyoid Masseter Temporalis Tensor tympani Tensor palati
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) All except 4 Explanation: Arch Nerve of arch Artery of arch Skeletal derivatives Muscles of arch First Maxillary (Sensory) and mandibular (Motor and sensory) branches of trigeminal nerve Maxillary artery Meckel's cartilage Malleus Incus Anterior ligament of malleus Sphenomandibular ligament Mandible Maxilla Zygomatic Palatine Temporal (part) Masseter Temporalis Medial pterygoid Lateral pterygoids Mylohyoid Anterior belly of digastric Tensor tympani, and Tensor palati All are migratory except T. tympani (Option D) Pharyngeal arch Muscles First Masseter Temporalis Medial pterygoid Lateral pterygoids Mylohyoid Anterior belly of digastric Tensor tympani, and Tensor palati Second Stapedius Stylohyoid Posterior belly of digastric Epicranius Orbicularis oculi Orbicularis oris Zygomaticus Buccinator Nasal muscles Platysma Levator labii superioris, levator labii inferioris Levator anguli oris Auricular muscles Third Stylopharyngeus Fourth Larynx–Cricothyroid Muscles of pharynx Intrinsic muscles of soft palate except tensor palati Sixth All intrinsic muscles of larynx except cricothyroid Reference: Inderbir Singh’s Human Embryology 11th edition, page 129, 130

questions.question: Which among the following are formed from Reichert's cartilage? Stapes Styloid process Stylohyoid ligament Lesser cornu of hyoid Upper half of body of hyoid
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) All the above Explanation: Arch Nerve of arch Artery of arch Skeletal derivatives Muscles of arch Second Facial nerve Hyoid artery Stapedial artery The cartilage of the second arch (Reichert’s) forms the following: (Option A) Stapes Styloid process Stylohyoid ligament Lesser cornu of hyoid Upper half of body of hyoid Stapedius Stylohyoid Posterior belly of digastric Epicranius Orbicularis oculi Orbicularis oris Zygomaticus Buccinator Nasal muscles Platysma Levator labii superioris, levator labii inferioris Levator anguli oris Auricular muscles All are migratory except stapedius, stylohyoid Reference: Inderbir Singh’s Human Embryology, 11th Edition, Page 129, 130.

questions.question: Match the following pharyngeal arch to its corresponding nerve and artery derivatives. Arch Nerve of arch Artery of arch 1) Fourth a) Superior laryngeal nerve (Vagus) i) Arch of aorta ii) Subclavian artery 2) Sixth b) Recurrent laryngeal nerve (vagus) iii) Ductus arteriosus iv) Pulmonary artery
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Option B and C Explanation: Arch Nerve of arch Artery of arch Skeletal derivatives Muscles of arch Fourth Superior laryngeal branch of vagus nerve Arch of aorta (left side) Subclavian artery (right side) Thyroid Cricoid Corniculate Cuneiform Arytenoid Thyrohyoid ligament Epiglottis: From mesodermal core of hypobranchial eminence Larynx: Cricothyroid Muscles of pharynx Intrinsic muscles of soft palate except tensor palati Sixth Recurrent laryngeal branch of vagus nerve Ductus arteriosus (left side) Pulmonary artery (right side) All intrinsic muscles of larynx except cricothyroid Note: High-pitch phonation is controlled by the cricothyroid muscle, which develops from the 4th pharyngeal arch and is innervated by the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve. Reference: Inderbir Singh’s Human Embryology, 11th Edition, Page 129, 130.

questions.question: Match the pharyngeal arches to the nerves arising from it. Pharyngeal arch Nerve tympani d. Sixth 4. Recurrent laryngeal nerve
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) a-3, b-1, c-2, d-4 Explanation: Pharyngeal Arch Pretrematic Nerve Post Trematic Nerve First Chorda tympani (branch of facial nerve) Maxillary (sensory) and mandibular (motor & sensory) branches of trigeminal nerve (CN V) Second Possible: Tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) Facial nerve (CN VII) Third Possible: Auricular branch of vagus nerve (CN X) Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) Fourth - Superior laryngeal branch of vagus nerve (CN X) Sixth - Recurrent laryngeal branch of vagus nerve (CN X) Reference: Inderbir Singh’s Human Embryology, 11th Edition, Page 129, 130.

questions.question: Which of the following is the correct pairing of the pharyngeal pouch with its derivative?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 2nd pharyngeal pouch-Tonsillar fossa Explanation: Pharyngeal Pouch Derivatives 1st Pharyngeal Pouch Tympanic cavity Auditory tube Inner surface of the eardrum 2nd Pharyngeal Pouch Palatine tonsil Tonsillar fossa 3rd Pharyngeal Pouch Thymus Inferior parathyroid glands 4th Pharyngeal Pouch Superior parathyroid glands Thyroid gland Reference: Inderbir Singh’s Human Embryology, 11th Edition, Page 131, 132.

questions.question: Match the pharyngeal arch with the artery developing from it Pharyngeal arch Artery a. First 1. Hyoid artery b. Second 2. Maxillary artery c. Third 3. Arch of aorta
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) a-2, b-1, c-4, d-3 Explanation: Pharyngeal Arch Artery of Arch First Maxillary artery Second Hyoid artery , Stapedial artery Third Common carotid artery, Internal carotid artery Fourth Arch of aorta (left side), Subclavian artery (right side) Sixth Ductus arteriosus (left side), Pulmonary artery (right side) Reference: Inderbir Singh’s Human Embryology, 11th Edition, Page 130.

questions.question: Which of the following nerves provides general sensation to the area of the tongue marked in blue?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Lingual nerve Explanation: Nerve supply of tongue: Sensory innervation: Part of Tongue General Sensation Taste Sensation Anterior two-third Trigeminal nerve (V3) (specifically the lingual branch) Chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve (CN VII) Posterior one-third Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) Root of the tongue and the area around the epiglottis Vagus nerve (CN X) Vagus nerve (CN X) Motor innervation: The hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) provides motor innervation to all of the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue except for the palatoglossus muscle, which is innervated by the vagus nerve (CN X).
